title: Assessing imbalance
text: example, use dataset included within package: dataset contains four variables:- two stratification variables, two randomisation variables. One randomisation variable, rando_res balanced randomisation. , rando_res2, small degree imbalance.
code: data(rando_balance) summary(rando_balance) #>      strat1        strat2     rando_res          rando_res2        #>  Min.   :0.0   Min.   :0.0   Length:100         Length:100         #>  1st Qu.:0.0   1st Qu.:0.0   Class :character   Class :character   #>  Median :0.5   Median :0.5   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   #>  Mean   :0.5   Mean   :0.5                                         #>  3rd Qu.:1.0   3rd Qu.:1.0                                         #>  Max.   :1.0   Max.   :1.0 table(rando_balance$rando_res) #>  #> trt1 trt2  #>   50   50 table(rando_balance$rando_res2) #>  #> trt1 trt2  #>   53   47

title: Assessing imbalance
text: imbalance_seq_plots function aids plotting imbalance function randomisation number (assuming data sorted oldest newest). function produces 6 plots, patchwork package comes useful combining plots via wrap_plots.  left see balance observed data. right, see simulated dataset completely random assignment. generally want observed curve randomly generated data. stratification variables included, additional plots shown lines level stratification variable(s) (second row) specific strata (combination stratification variable; last row).
code: library(patchwork) imbalance_seq_plots(rando_balance,                      randovar = "rando_res") |>    wrap_plots(ncol = 2) imbalance_seq_plots(rando_balance,                      randovar = "rando_res",                     stratavars = c("strat1", "strat2")) |>    wrap_plots(ncol = 2)

title: Assessing imbalance
text: also provide permutation-type test, accompanying plot, comparing observed randomisation imbalance multiple simulated datasets. null hypothesis test imbalance lower equal random data relative observed data. , want small p-value. corresponding plots show frequency imbalance values random datasets (bars). red vertical line indicates observed data. Ideally, observed line left plot. p-value indicated bottom right.
code: imb <- imbalance_test(rando_balance,                        randovar = "rando_res2",                       stratavars = c("strat1", "strat2")) imb #> Randomisations to date: 100  #> Overall imbalance: 6  #>   Probability of less imbalance from random allocation: 0.498  #>  #> Randomisation stratified by strat1 and strat2  #> Maximum observed imbalanced within stratifying variables: 4  #>   Probability of less imbalance from random allocation: 0.355  #> Maximum observed imbalanced within individual strata: 5  #>   Probability of less imbalance from random allocation: 0.364 imbalance_test_plot(imb)

title: randotools
text: Randomisation lists easily created randolist function. Specify number participants randomise (per strata, ), strata, arms randomise , block sizes. call, n specifies number participants randomise per stratum. case, randomising 20 participants single stratum. arms specifies names arms randomise . number arms can specified, randolist can used trials two, three, even 10 arms, platform trials can accommodated randolist, although implementing within database trivial.

title: randotools
text: default, randolist uses block randomisation - rather using random selection along whole list hope arms balanced, creates blocks randomisation, whereby block balanced, block sizes chosen random. helps balancing, also makes harder guess next allocation. Block sizes controlled via blocksizes argument, values potential number arm include given block. E.g. c(1,2) produce blocks either one arm, two arm, total block size 2 4. Additionally, blocksizes selected approximately proportional Pascal’s Triangle, medium sizes blocks likely selected small large blocks. done ensure randomisation list predictable, helps balance reducing chance finishing mid-way large block. disable block randomisation, set block size n divided number arms (case n/2, 10): blockrand function can also used non-stratified randomisation lists.

title: randotools
text: common need stratified randomisation randomisation balanced within strata. done specifying strata argument, list stratifying variables. function create randomisation list stratum, combine single list. list strata contains n participants. using factors specify strata, labels levels available use exporting randomisation list, useful importing electronic data capture systems REDCap, requires specific format.
code: rs <- randolist(n = 10,                  strata = list(sex = c("Male", "Female"),                               age = c("Teen", "Adult")))  table(rs$sex) #>  #>   Male Female  #>     20     24 table(rs$sex, rs$arm) #>          #>           A  B #>   Male   10 10 #>   Female 12 12

title: randotools
text: uncommon unbalanced randomisation lists. E.g. 2 control participants per experimental participant. easily done changing arms argument: Adaptive trials sometimes modify randomisation balance part way trial, can accomplished via method.
code: r2 <- randolist(n = 10,                 arms = c("A", "A", "B"))  table(r2$arm) #>  #>  A  B  #> 10  5

title: randotools
text: can helpful summarize randomisation list check requirements, balance, coding, etc, met. randolist package includes summary precisely purpose: summary stratified randomisation lists also includes information strata level.
code: randolist(n = 20, arms = c("Trt1", "Trt2")) |> summary() #> ---- Randomisation list report ---- #> -- Overall #> Total number of randomisations:  22  #> Randomisation groups:  Trt1 : Trt2  #> Randomisation ratio: 1:1  #> Randomisations to each arm: #> Trt1 Trt2  #>   11   11  #> Block sizes: #> 2 4 6  #> 1 2 2

title: randotools
text: randomisation list created, needs transferred system ultimately perform randomisation. primarily use two systems : REDCap SecuTrial, might use others, may require modifications. randolist package includes function convert randomisation list format , minimal effort, importable systems. randolist_to_db function used convert randomisation list format can imported system. function takes randomisation list input, converts data frame columns appropriate target database (target_db). case REDCap, necessary provide data frame maps arms provided randolist database variables. SecuTrial uses standardised format, rando_encoding required. dataframe returned can exported CSV xlsx imported relevant database.
code: # create a very small randomisation list for demonstration purposes rs2 <- randolist(n = 2, blocksizes = 1,                  arms = c("Aspirin", "Placebo"),                  strata = list(sex = c("Male", "Female"),                                age = c("Teen", "Adult"))) randolist_to_db(rs2, target_db = "REDCap",                  rando_enc = data.frame(arm = c("Aspirin", "Placebo"),                                        rand_result = c(1, 2)),                 strata_enc = list(sex = data.frame(sex = c("Male", "Female"), code = 1:2),                                   age = data.frame(age = c("Teen", "Adult"), code = 1:2))) #>   rand_result sex age #> 1           1   1   1 #> 2           2   1   1 #> 3           2   2   1 #> 4           1   2   1 #> 5           1   1   2 #> 6           2   1   2 #> 7           2   2   2 #> 8           1   2   2 randolist_to_db(rs2, target_db = "secuTrial",                 strata_enc = list(sex = data.frame(sex = c("Male", "Female"), code = 1:2),                                   age = data.frame(age = c("Teen", "Adult"), code = 1:2))) #>   Number   Group       sex       age #> 1      1 Aspirin value = 1 value = 1 #> 2      2 Placebo value = 1 value = 1 #> 3      3 Placebo value = 2 value = 1 #> 4      4 Aspirin value = 2 value = 1 #> 5      5 Aspirin value = 1 value = 2 #> 6      6 Placebo value = 1 value = 2 #> 7      7 Placebo value = 2 value = 2 #> 8      8 Aspirin value = 2 value = 2

title: Authors and Citation
text: Alan G Haynes. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Haynes AG (2025). randotools: Create Randomization Lists R. R package version 0.1.0, https://ctu-bern.github.io/randolist/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {randotools: Create Randomization Lists From R},   author = {Alan G Haynes},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://ctu-bern.github.io/randolist/}, }

title: Create Randomization Lists From R
text: randotools contains functions creating randomisation lists, related tasks, R.

title: Create Randomization Lists From R
text: can install development version randotools github :
code: remotes::install_github("CTU-Bern/randotools")

title: Create Randomization Lists From R
text: Generate randomisation list randolist. Create short summary randomisation list summary. Export randomisation list database compatible format randolist_to_db.
code: library(randotools) set.seed(123) r <- randolist(50, arms = c("Trt1", "Trt2"), strata = list(sex = c("Female", "Male"))) summary(r) #> ---- Randomisation list report ---- #> -- Overall #> Total number of randomisations:  106  #> Randomisation groups:  Trt1 : Trt2  #> Randomisation ratio: 1:1  #> Randomisations to each arm: #> Trt1 Trt2  #>   53   53  #> Block sizes: #>  2  4  6  #>  9 13  6  #> -- Stratifier level  #> Randomisation list is stratified by variables sex  #> -  1  #> Randomisations per level of sex : #> Female   Male  #>     54     52  #> Balance per level of sex :         #>          Trt1 Trt2 #>   Female   27   27 #>   Male     26   26 #> -- Stratum level  #> 2 strata are defined: #>  #> Female   Male  #>     54     52  #> -  Female  #> Number of randomisations:  54 #> Trt1 Trt2  #>   27   27  #> Block sizes:  #> 2 4 6  #> 5 5 4  #> -  Male  #> Number of randomisations:  52 #> Trt1 Trt2  #>   26   26  #> Block sizes:  #> 2 4 6  #> 4 8 2 randolist_to_db(r, target_db = "REDCap",                 strata_enc = list(sex = data.frame(sex = c("Female", "Male"),                                                    code = 1:2)),                 rando_enc = data.frame(arm = c("Trt1", "Trt2"),                                        rand_result = 1:2)                 )

title: Create Randomization Lists From R
text: Development package funded part via grant Swiss Clinical Trial Organization Statistics Methodology Platform. package logo created ggplot2 hexSticker icons Font Awesome.

what: Depict the imbalance of a randomisation sequence through time — imbalance_seq_plots
title: Depict the imbalance of a randomisation sequence through time — imbalance_seq_plots
text: can useful see imbalance changes time. function allows depiction plotting maximum imbalance function randomisation number (assuming observations randomisation order). especially useful case randomisation via minimisation. well overall imbalance, function also depicts imbalance within strata (.e. interaction among stratifying variables) within strata identified stratifying variable .

title: Depict the imbalance of a randomisation sequence through time — imbalance_seq_plots
code: imbalance_seq_plots(data, randovar, stratavars = NULL, cross = TRUE)

title: Depict the imbalance of a randomisation sequence through time — imbalance_seq_plots
text: data data frame randovar variable name containing randomisation result stratavars variable names stratification variables cross logical whether cross stratification variables create individual strata

title: Depict the imbalance of a randomisation sequence through time — imbalance_seq_plots
text: six ggplots. randomisation sequence along x-axis imbalance y-axis. different lines denotes different groupings. plots paired: first plot shows observed balance, second shows balance simulated dataset. three pairs plots. First overall values shown. Second, line represents group defined stratification variables. E.g., 2-level stratification variable 3-level variable, 5 lines. third pair shows individual strata - combination stratification variables. 2- 3-level example mentioned , result 6 lines. can skipped setting cross FALSE.

title: Depict the imbalance of a randomisation sequence through time — imbalance_seq_plots
code: data(rando_balance) # without stratification variables imbalance_seq_plots(rando_balance, "rando_res") #> Calculating sequential imbalance (overall) #> Calculating simulated sequential imbalance (overall) #> $overall_observed  #>  #> $overall_simulated  #>  # with stratification factors imbalance_seq_plots(rando_balance, "rando_res",                     c("strat1", "strat2")) #> Calculating sequential imbalance (overall) #> Calculating simulated sequential imbalance (overall) #> Calculating sequential imbalance (strata) #> Calculating simulated sequential imbalance (strata) #> $overall_observed  #>  #> $overall_simulated  #>  #> $strata_observed  #>  #> $strata_simulated  #>  #> $stratavar_oberved  #>  #> $stratavar_simulated  #>  # do not cross the stratification factors imbalance_seq_plots(rando_balance, "rando_res",                     c("strat1", "strat2"),                     cross = FALSE) #> Calculating sequential imbalance (overall) #> Calculating simulated sequential imbalance (overall) #> Calculating sequential imbalance (strata) #> Calculating simulated sequential imbalance (strata) #> $overall_observed  #>  #> $overall_simulated  #>  #> $stratavar_oberved  #>  #> $stratavar_simulated  #>

what: Test the imbalance of randomisation via simulation — imbalance_test
title: Test the imbalance of randomisation via simulation — imbalance_test
text: function tests whether observed imbalance less might expected via random draw, via permutation test.

title: Test the imbalance of randomisation via simulation — imbalance_test
code: imbalance_test(   data,   randovar,   n_iter = 1000,   stratavars = NULL,   arms = NULL,   cross = TRUE,   ... )

title: Test the imbalance of randomisation via simulation — imbalance_test
text: data dataframe variables indicated randovar , optionally, stratavars randovar character variable name indicating randomisation n_iter integer. number simulations perform stratavars character vector variable names indicating stratification variables arms character vector arms appropriate balance. NULL levels randovar used assumed balanced cross logical. Whether cross stratification variables. ... arguments passed onto methods

title: Test the imbalance of randomisation via simulation — imbalance_test
text: list : n_rando: number randomisations stratavars: names stratification variables arms: arms observed: dataframe observed imbalance simulated: dataframe simulated imbalances (number rows = nrow(n_iter)) tests: dataframe p-values

title: Test the imbalance of randomisation via simulation — imbalance_test
code: data(rando_balance) # without stratification variables imbalance_test(rando_balance, "rando_res") #> assuming balanced randomisation between arms #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                 52% | ETA:  2s #> Randomisations to date: 100  #> Overall imbalance: 0  #>   Probability of less imbalance from random allocation: 0.072  imb <- imbalance_test(rando_balance, "rando_res", stratavars = "strat1") #> assuming balanced randomisation between arms #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■                        31% | ETA:  9s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■         78% | ETA:  3s imbalance_test(rando_balance, "rando_res", stratavars = c("strat1", "strat2")) #> assuming balanced randomisation between arms #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■                              11% | ETA: 27s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■                        32% | ETA: 20s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■ Maximum observed imbalanced within stratifying variables: 0  #>   Probability of less imbalance from random allocation: 0.079  #> Maximum observed imbalanced within individual strata: 3  #> what: Plot imbalance and simulation and test results — imbalance_test_plot
title: Plot imbalance and simulation and test results — imbalance_test_plot
text: Plot histograms imbalance values simulation results vertical lines indicate observed imbalance randomisation level (overall, stratification variable level, strata level, appropriate). p-values tests included figure captions.

title: Plot imbalance and simulation and test results — imbalance_test_plot
code: imbalance_test_plot(test, vline_col = "red", stack = TRUE)

title: Plot imbalance and simulation and test results — imbalance_test_plot
text: test imbalance_test object vline_col colour vertical line indicating observed imbalance stack logical, whether use patchwork::wrap_plots stack plots one column (TRUE) return list ggplot objects (FALSE)

title: Plot imbalance and simulation and test results — imbalance_test_plot
code: # example code data(rando_balance) # without stratification variables imb <- imbalance_test(rando_balance, "rando_res2", stratavars = c("strat1", "strat2")) #> assuming balanced randomisation between arms #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■                            17% | ETA: 24s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■                      38% | ETA: 18s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                  48% | ETA: 15s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■               59% | ETA: 12s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■            69% | ETA:  9s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■         80% | ETA:  6s #> Simulating randomisations ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■      90% | ETA:  3s imbalance_test_plot(imb)

title: rando_balance demonstration dataset — rando_balance
text: synthetic dataset used examples. dataset contains two randomisation result variables (rando_res rando_res2) two stratification variables (strat1 strat2).

title: rando_balance demonstration dataset — rando_balance
code: rando_balance

title: rando_balance demonstration dataset — rando_balance
text: data frame 100 rows 3 columns: strat1, strat2 Binary stratification variables rando_res Balanced randomisation result rando_res2 Unbalanced randomisation result

title: Generate randomisation lists — randolist
text: Randomisation lists central randomised trials. function allows generate randomisation lists simply, via (optionally) stratified block randomisation

title: Generate randomisation lists — randolist
code: randolist(   n,   arms = LETTERS[1:2],   strata = NA,   blocksizes = 1:3,   pascal = TRUE,   ... )

title: Generate randomisation lists — randolist
text: n total number randomizations (per stratum) arms arms randomise strata named list stratification variables (see examples) blocksizes numbers arm include blocks (see details) pascal logical, whether use pascal's triangle determine block sizes ... arguments passed methods

title: Generate randomisation lists — randolist
text: blocksizes defines number allocations arm block. example, two arms, blocksizes = 1, block contain 2 randomisations. blocksizes = 1:2, block contain either one arm, two arm. Total block sizes therefore  blocksizes * length(arms). default, frequency different block sizes determined using Pascal's triangle. advantage small large block sizes less common intermediate sized blocks, helps making difficult guess future allocations, reduces risk finishing middle large block. Unbalanced randomization possible specifying arm label multiple times. disable block randomisation, set blocksizes value n.

title: Generate randomisation lists — randolist
code: # example code randolist(10) #>    seq_in_strata block_in_strata blocksize seq_in_block arm #> 1              1               1         4            1   B #> 2              2               1         4            2   A #> 3              3               1         4            3   B #> 4              4               1         4            4   A #> 5              5               2         6 #> 9              9               2         6            5   B #> 10            10               2         6            6   B # one stratifying variable randolist(10, strata = list(sex = c("M", "F"))) #>    stratum seq_in_strata block_in_strata blocksize seq_in_block arm sex #> 1        1             1               1         2            1   B   M #> 2        1             2               1 1               1         4            1   B   F #> 14       2             2               1         4            2   A   F #> 15       2             3               1         4            3   B   F #> 16       2             4               1         4            4   A   F #> 17       2             5               2         6            1   A   F #> 18       2             6               2 9               2         6            5   A   F #> 22       2            10               2         6            6   B   F #>    strata_txt #> 1           M #> 2           M #> 3           M #> 4 what: Reformat a randolist object to the requirements of a database — randolist_to_db
title: Reformat a randolist object to the requirements of a database — randolist_to_db
text: Databases generally require specific format able import randomization list. function converts randolist object format required REDCap secuTrial.

title: Reformat a randolist object to the requirements of a database — randolist_to_db
code: randolist_to_db(   randolist,   target_db = c("REDCap", "secuTrial"),   strata_enc = NA,   rando_enc = NA )

title: Reformat a randolist object to the requirements of a database — randolist_to_db
text: randolist randolist object randolist blockrand target_db target database, either "REDCap" "secuTrial" strata_enc list data frames encoding stratification variable. two columns - value used randolist code values used database. See examples details. rando_enc data frame randomization encoding

title: Reformat a randolist object to the requirements of a database — randolist_to_db
text: rando_enc contain arm column containing values supplied randolist, variable name required database values map arm. See examples.

title: Reformat a randolist object to the requirements of a database — randolist_to_db
code: r <- randolist(10,                strata = list(sex = c("M", "F")),                arms = c("T1", "T2")) randolist_to_db(r,   rando_enc = data.frame(arm = c("T1", "T2"),                         rando_res = c(1, 2)),   strata_enc = list(sex = data.frame(sex = c("M", "F"),                                     code = 1:2)),   target_db = "REDCap") #>    rando_res sex #> 1          2   1 #> 2          1   1 #> 3          2   1 #> 4          1   1 #> 5          1   1 #> 6          2   1 #> 7          1   1 #> 8          2   1 #> 9          2   1 #> 10         1   1 #> 11         2   1 #> 12         1   1 #> 13         1   2 #> 14         2   2 #> 15         2   2 #> 16         2   2 #> 17         1   2 #> 18         1   2 #> 19         2   2 #> 20         1   2 #> 21         2   2 #> 22         2   2 #> 23         1   2 #> 24         1   2 randolist_to_db(r,   rando_enc = data.frame(arm = c("T1", "T2"),                          rando_res = c(1, 2)),   strata_enc = list(sex = data.frame(sex = c("M", "F"),                                      code = 1:2)),   target_db = "secuTrial") #> Warning: rando_enc ignored for secuTrial #> Warning: The SecuTrial target is untested and may require some adjustment #>    Number Group       sex #> 1       1    T2 value = 1 #> 2       2    T1 value = 1 #> 3       3    T2 value = 1 #> 4       4    T1 value = 1 #> 5       5    T1 value = 1 #> 6       6    T2 value = 1 #> 7       7    T1 value = 1 #> 8       8    T2 value = 1 #> 9       9    T2 value = 1 #> 10     10    T1 value = 1 #> 11     11    T2 value = 1 #> 12     12    T1 value = 1 #> 13     13    T1 value = 2 #> 14     14    T2 value = 2 #> 15     15    T2 value = 2 #> 16     16    T2 value = 2 #> 17     17    T1 value = 2 #> 18     18    T1 value = 2 #> 19     19    T2 value = 2 #> 20     20    T1 value = 2 #> 21     21    T2 value = 2 #> 22     22    T2 value = 2 #> 23     23    T1 value = 2 #> 24     24    T1 value = 2

what: Summary method fro randolist objects — summary.randolist
title: Summary method fro randolist objects — summary.randolist
text: Create short summary report aspects randomisation list, used quality control.

title: Summary method fro randolist objects — summary.randolist
code: # S3 method for class 'randolist' summary(object, ...)

title: Summary method fro randolist objects — summary.randolist
text: object randolist object ... additional arguments (currently unused)

title: Summary method fro randolist objects — summary.randolist
code: r <- randolist(20) print(summary(r)) #> ---- Randomisation list report ---- #> -- Overall #> Total number of randomisations:  20  #> Randomisation groups:  A : B  #> Randomisation ratio: 1:1  #> Randomisations to each arm: #>  A  B  #> 10 10  #> Block sizes: #> 2 4 6  #> 1 3 1   r2 <- randolist(20, strata = list(sex = c("M", "F"))) print(summary(r2)) #> ---- Randomisation list report ---- #> -- Overall #> Total number of randomisations:  42  #> Randomisation groups:  A : B  #> Randomisation ratio: 1:1  #> Randomisations to each arm: #>  A  B  #> 21 21  #> Block sizes: #> 2 4 6  #> 4 4 3  #> -- Stratifier level  #> Randomisation list is stratified by variables sex  #> -  1  #> Randomisations per level of sex : #>  M  F  #> 22 20  #> Balance per level of sex :    #>      A  B #>   M 11 11 #>   F 10 10 #> -- Stratum level  #> 2 strata are defined: #>  #>  F  M  #> 20 22  #> -  F  #> Number of randomisations:  22 #>  A  B  #> 11 11  #> Block sizes:  #> 2 4 6  #> 4 2 1  #> -  M  #> Number of randomisations:  20 #>  A  B  #> 10 10  #> Block sizes:  #> 4 6  #> 2 2  #> [[1]] #>  #> 2 4 6  #> 4 2 1  #>  #> [[2]] #>  #> 4 6  #> 2 2  #>   # NOTE: explicitly printing isn't technically necessary

title: randotools 0.1.0
text: addition tools assess balance randomised elements

title: randotools 0.0.4
text: Package renamed randotools allow flexibility includes randolist_to_db : Move randomisation result first column exporting REDCap summary : Remove use cli messages, appear sinked output Add vignette show use package
